uniqueRequirements: The test is strictly split: You must pass a 'Regulatory Signs' recognition test (identifying signs by shape/color only) BEFORE you can take the 25-question written knowledge test
Level 1 Limited Learner Permit holders can only drive between 5 AM and 9 PM for the first 6 months
Under the 'Fender Bender' law, you must move your vehicle to the shoulder if involved in a minor crash with no injuries
Must have a 'Driving Eligibility Certificate' from your school to prove you are passing your classes

questions.questionText: Under the Graduated Licensing Law, a Level 2 Limited Provisional License holder may drive without supervision only between the hours of:
questions.explanation: A Level 2 Limited Provisional License holder may drive without supervision from 5:00 AM to 9:00 PM. Driving outside these hours requires supervision or a specific work/volunteer exception.

questions.questionText: Conviction of which offense carries the highest number of driver license points (5 points) in North Carolina?
questions.explanation: Passing a stopped school bus that is loading or unloading children carries 5 driver license points, the highest for a non-commercial violation.

questions.questionText: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit inside cities and towns is:
questions.explanation: Unless otherwise posted, the standard speed limit within cities and towns in North Carolina is 35 mph.

questions.questionText: When windshield wipers are in use because of inclement weather, you must also:
questions.explanation: North Carolina law requires that motorists turn on their headlights whenever they are using their windshield wipers due to bad weather.

questions.questionText: If you refuse to take a chemical test (breathalyzer) when charged with DWI, your license will be revoked immediately for at least:
questions.explanation: Refusing to perform any required test will result in the immediate revocation of your driver license for at least 30 days and an additional, minimum 12-month revocation by the DMV.

questions.questionText: The 'Two-Second Rule' is used to determine:

answers.text: How long to stop at a stop sign
How long to signal before turning

questions.explanation: The 'Two-Second Rule' helps you maintain a safe following distance. Allow two seconds of space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead.

questions.questionText: When approaching a traffic circle (roundabout), you must:

answers.text: Yield to vehicles already in the circle

questions.explanation: Traffic in a roundabout moves counter-clockwise. You must yield the right-of-way to vehicles already circulating within the roundabout.

questions.questionText: It is illegal for any person under age 18 to use a cell phone while driving:

answers.text: At any time, except in an emergency

questions.explanation: Drivers under 18 are prohibited from using any mobile telephone or technology associated with a mobile telephone while the vehicle is in motion, except in emergencies.

questions.questionText: If you are driving on a two-lane roadway with a center turning lane, and a school bus stops with red flashing lights on the opposite side:

answers.text: You do not need to stop
You must stop only if children are present
You should slow down to 10 mph

questions.explanation: On a two-lane road with a center turning lane, traffic from BOTH directions must stop for a school bus with flashing red lights.

questions.questionText: Hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as:
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning, where tires lose contact with the road due to water, can start at speeds as low as 30 mph if the water is deep enough and tires are worn.

questions.questionText: When driving in fog, you should use:
questions.explanation: Use low beam headlights in fog. High beams reflect off the water particles in the fog, causing glare that makes it harder to see.

questions.questionText: At an intersection without traffic signs or signals, you must yield to:
questions.explanation: At uncontrolled intersections, the vehicle on the left must yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on the right.

questions.questionText: When entering an interstate highway, you should use the acceleration lane to:

answers.text: Stop and wait for a gap
Match the speed of traffic and merge when safe
Drive slowly until you find an opening

questions.explanation: Use the acceleration lane to speed up and match the flow of traffic on the interstate before merging.

questions.questionText: Farm equipment and other slow-moving vehicles usually travel at speeds of:
questions.explanation: Farm equipment usually travels 15-25 mph. Drivers should approach them with caution and be prepared to slow down.

questions.questionText: You are not allowed to park within ___ feet of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: Do not park within 15 feet of a fire hydrant in North Carolina.

questions.questionText: When parking near a curb, your vehicle must be within ___ inches of the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking parallel to the curb, your vehicle should be within 12 inches of the curb.

questions.questionText: If your vehicle breaks down, you should:

answers.text: Stand in the road to flag down help
Move the vehicle off the paved portion of the road
Leave the vehicle where it is
Sit inside with no lights on

questions.explanation: If possible, move your vehicle completely off the paved portion of the road to the shoulder. Turn on emergency flashers.

questions.questionText: A pennant-shaped yellow sign on the left side of the road indicates:
questions.explanation: The pennant (sideways triangle) shape is exclusively used to mark the beginning of a No Passing Zone.

questions.questionText: An eight-sided red sign means:
questions.explanation: The octagon is exclusively used for STOP signs.

questions.questionText: A diamond-shaped sign with an orange background indicates:
questions.explanation: Orange diamond signs are used to warn drivers of construction and maintenance work zones.

questions.questionText: A circular yellow sign with a black 'X' and 'RR' means:
questions.explanation: The round yellow sign is the advance warning sign for a railroad crossing.

questions.questionText: A five-sided (pentagon) sign indicates:
questions.explanation: The pentagon shape is reserved for school zones and school crossings. Drive with caution.

questions.questionText: A white rectangular sign indicates:
questions.explanation: Vertical white rectangles are regulatory signs that tell you about traffic laws (e.g., Speed Limit, No Left Turn).

questions.questionText: A red and white inverted triangle sign means:
questions.explanation: The inverted triangle is the standard shape for a Yield sign.

questions.questionText: A yellow diamond-shaped sign indicates:
questions.explanation: Yellow diamond signs are warning signs that alert you to potential hazards or changes in road conditions.

questions.questionText: A square orange sign with black lettering means:
questions.explanation: Square orange signs indicate work zones or construction areas where workers may be present.

questions.questionText: A red circle with a red line through it means:
questions.explanation: A red circle with a diagonal red line through it is the international prohibition symbol, indicating that the pictured action is not allowed.

questions.questionText: Green signs on highways provide:
questions.explanation: Green signs provide directional guidance and distance information on highways and expressways.

questions.questionText: Blue service signs indicate:

answers.text: Motorist services like food, gas, lodging

questions.explanation: Blue signs provide information about motorist services such as rest areas, gas stations, food, and lodging.

questions.questionText: Brown signs indicate:

answers.text: Recreational areas and points of interest

questions.explanation: Brown signs provide information about recreational facilities, historic sites, and scenic areas.

questions.questionText: A flashing yellow traffic signal means:

answers.text: Speed up to clear the intersection

questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light warns you to slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.questionText: A flashing red traffic signal means:
questions.explanation: A flashing red signal means the same as a stop sign - you must come to a complete stop and proceed when safe.

questions.questionText: What does a yellow 'X' above a lane mean?

answers.text: Lane is for emergency vehicles only
Prepare to leave the lane safely

questions.explanation: A yellow 'X' signal indicates that the lane will soon be closed and drivers should prepare to move to another lane.

questions.questionText: A red 'X' displayed above a lane means:

answers.text: The lane is closed to traffic

questions.explanation: A red 'X' means the lane is closed and you must not drive in that lane.

questions.questionText: A sign with a picture of a truck going downhill means:
questions.explanation: This sign warns of a steep grade or hill, particularly important for trucks and heavy vehicles.

questions.questionText: A sign showing a car with skid marks means:
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the road may be slippery when wet, requiring reduced speed and increased caution.

questions.questionText: A sign with two arrows pointing in opposite directions means:
questions.explanation: This sign warns that you are approaching a section of road where traffic flows in both directions.

questions.questionText: A diamond-shaped sign with a picture of a deer means:
questions.explanation: This sign warns drivers to watch for deer and other wildlife that may cross the road.

questions.questionText: A sign showing a bicycle means:
questions.explanation: This sign warns motorists to watch for bicycles crossing or sharing the roadway.

questions.questionText: A sign with a picture of a traffic signal ahead means:

answers.text: Signal ahead where you may not expect one

questions.explanation: This sign warns that there is a traffic signal ahead, often in a location where drivers might not expect one.

questions.questionText: A sign showing a merging arrow means:
questions.explanation: This sign warns that two lanes of traffic will merge into one lane ahead.

questions.questionText: A sign with a winding road symbol means:
questions.explanation: This sign warns of a series of curves or turns ahead, requiring reduced speed.

questions.questionText: A 'WRONG WAY' sign is usually paired with what other sign?
questions.explanation: Wrong Way signs are typically found with Do Not Enter signs to warn drivers they are heading the wrong direction.

questions.questionText: A white rectangular sign with 'ONLY' written below an arrow means:

answers.text: Traffic must move in the direction shown

questions.explanation: This lane use control sign indicates that traffic in that lane must move only in the direction of the arrow.

questions.questionText: A sign reading 'SLOWER TRAFFIC KEEP RIGHT' means:

answers.text: Slow vehicles should use the right lane

questions.explanation: This sign reminds slower-moving vehicles to stay in the right lane to allow faster traffic to pass on the left.

questions.questionText: A sign showing a divided highway symbol means:
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the highway ahead is divided with a median or barrier separating opposing traffic.

questions.questionText: What shape is a stop sign?
questions.explanation: A stop sign is always an octagon (eight-sided), the only sign that uses this shape.

questions.questionText: A sign with a large arrow curving to the right or left means:

answers.text: Sharp curve ahead in the direction of the arrow

questions.explanation: A large curved arrow sign warns of a sharp curve ahead in the direction the arrow points.

questions.questionText: A circular sign with a diagonal line through a turn arrow means:
questions.explanation: This regulatory sign prohibits turns in the direction shown by the crossed-out arrow.

questions.questionText: A yellow warning sign with black arrows showing one arrow going straight and another turning means:

answers.text: You can go straight or turn

questions.explanation: This sign warns of an intersection ahead where traffic may be turning.

questions.questionText: What does a white 'X' shaped sign with black 'RR' letters indicate?
questions.explanation: The white X-shaped crossbuck sign marks a railroad crossing and requires drivers to yield to trains.

questions.questionText: A sign reading 'PED XING' means:
questions.explanation: 'PED XING' is an abbreviation for pedestrian crossing, warning drivers to watch for people crossing the road.

questions.questionText: A sign with 'SLOWER TRAFFIC KEEP RIGHT' specifically enforces:
questions.explanation: This sign enforces North Carolina's Slow Poke Law, requiring slower traffic to use the right lane on multi-lane highways.

questions.questionText: A diamond-shaped orange sign with 'FLAGGER AHEAD' means:

answers.text: Person directing traffic ahead in work zone

questions.explanation: This work zone sign warns that a person (flagger) will be directing traffic ahead, and you must obey their signals.

questions.questionText: A sign with 'ROAD WORK AHEAD' and an arrow pointing right means:

answers.text: Road work is on the right side
Merge right due to road work
Turn right to avoid road work

questions.explanation: The arrow indicates the location of the road work, warning drivers to expect construction activity on that side.

questions.questionText: A regulatory sign showing a red circle with '35' inside means:
questions.explanation: A number inside a red circle indicates the maximum speed limit for that area.

questions.questionText: A sign reading 'KEEP RIGHT' with an arrow means:

answers.text: Pass an obstruction on the right

questions.explanation: This sign directs traffic to pass an obstruction, median, or island on the right side.

questions.questionText: An orange sign with 'DETOUR' and an arrow means:

answers.text: Road closed, follow arrow for alternate route

questions.explanation: Detour signs direct traffic around road closures or construction to an alternate route.

questions.questionText: A yellow pennant-shaped sign is always placed:

answers.text: On the right side of the road
On the left side of the road

questions.explanation: The pennant-shaped No Passing Zone sign is always on the left side of the road, marking where passing is prohibited.

questions.questionText: When driving in heavy rain, you should:

answers.text: Increase speed to get through it quickly
Reduce speed and increase following distance
Turn off headlights to reduce glare

questions.explanation: In heavy rain, reduce your speed, increase following distance, and turn on headlights. Never use cruise control in wet conditions.

questions.questionText: If you experience a tire blowout while driving, you should:

answers.text: Hold the steering wheel firmly and gradually slow down

questions.explanation: During a blowout, grip the steering wheel firmly, ease off the gas pedal, and brake gently once you have control. Avoid sudden braking or turning.

questions.questionText: When approaching a curve, you should:

answers.text: Slow down before entering the curve

questions.explanation: Slow down before entering a curve, not while in it. Braking in a curve can cause loss of control.

questions.questionText: The safest way to exit an expressway is to:

answers.text: Slow down before reaching the exit ramp
Slow down on the exit ramp
Maintain highway speed until you exit
Brake hard at the last minute

questions.explanation: Maintain your speed on the highway and use the deceleration lane (exit ramp) to slow down to the posted ramp speed.

questions.questionText: When driving at night, you should:

answers.text: Reduce speed and use low beams in traffic
Follow other cars closely to see better

questions.explanation: At night, reduce speed and use low beams when following other vehicles or meeting oncoming traffic. Never 'overdrive' your headlights.

questions.questionText: If your brakes fail while driving, you should:
questions.explanation: If brakes fail, pump the brake pedal rapidly to build up brake fluid pressure. Downshift to lower gears and use the parking brake gently if needed.

questions.questionText: When being passed by another vehicle, you should:

answers.text: Move to the right and maintain your speed

questions.explanation: When being passed, stay in your lane, maintain a steady speed, and move to the right if possible to give the passing vehicle more room.

questions.questionText: You should use your horn:

answers.text: To alert other drivers of potential danger
To express anger at another driver

questions.explanation: Use your horn only to warn others of danger or to get attention when necessary, not to express frustration.

questions.questionText: The best way to handle a skid is to:

answers.text: Steer in the direction you want to go

questions.explanation: In a skid, ease off the gas, avoid braking, and steer in the direction you want the front of the car to go.

questions.questionText: When driving in work zones, you should:

answers.text: Watch for workers and obey posted signs
Use your phone to report delays

questions.explanation: In work zones, slow down, obey all posted signs and speed limits, stay alert for workers, and avoid distractions.

questions.questionText: If you are involved in a minor crash with no injuries, you should:

answers.text: Move vehicles to the shoulder if possible
Wait for police in the travel lane

questions.explanation: Under NC's 'Fender Bender' law, if there are no injuries and vehicles can be moved, you must move them to the shoulder to avoid blocking traffic.

questions.questionText: When should you use your high beam headlights?

answers.text: On open highways with no oncoming traffic

questions.explanation: Use high beams on open highways when there is no oncoming traffic and you are not following another vehicle. Dim them within 500 feet of oncoming traffic.

questions.questionText: If you are driving and feel drowsy, you should:
questions.explanation: The only safe solution to drowsy driving is to pull over in a safe location and rest or sleep.

questions.questionText: When driving on ice or snow, you should:

answers.text: Reduce speed and increase following distance

questions.explanation: On ice and snow, reduce speed significantly, increase following distance to 8-10 seconds, and avoid sudden movements.

questions.questionText: The 'Three-Second Rule' means:

answers.text: Maintain at least three seconds following distance

questions.explanation: The Three-Second Rule is a method to maintain safe following distance by keeping at least three seconds between your vehicle and the one ahead.

questions.questionText: When changing lanes, you should:

answers.text: Signal, check mirrors and blind spots, then change lanes

questions.explanation: Always signal first, check mirrors and blind spots, and then change lanes when safe. Make the signal early enough to warn other drivers.

questions.questionText: If your vehicle starts to hydroplane, you should:

answers.text: Ease off the gas and steer straight

questions.explanation: If you hydroplane, ease off the gas pedal, hold the steering wheel straight, and avoid braking until you regain traction.

questions.questionText: When backing up, you should:

answers.text: Turn and look over your shoulder

questions.explanation: When backing, turn your body and look over your shoulder in the direction you're backing. Also check mirrors and proceed slowly.

questions.questionText: Anti-lock brakes (ABS) help you:

answers.text: Maintain steering control while braking hard

questions.explanation: ABS prevents wheel lockup during hard braking, allowing you to maintain steering control. Apply steady, firm pressure to the brake pedal.

questions.questionText: A good defensive driver should:

answers.text: Expect other drivers to make mistakes
Always drive at the speed limit
Focus only on the car ahead

questions.explanation: Defensive driving means anticipating potential hazards and being prepared for mistakes by other drivers.

questions.questionText: When should you check your blind spots?
questions.explanation: Always check blind spots before changing lanes, merging, or turning. Mirrors alone cannot show everything.

questions.questionText: If you miss your exit on an interstate, you should:
questions.explanation: Never back up, stop, or turn around on an interstate. Continue to the next exit and find your way from there.

questions.questionText: When approaching a railroad crossing with flashing lights, you should:

answers.text: Stop and wait for the train
Slow down and look both ways

questions.explanation: When lights are flashing at a railroad crossing, you must stop at least 15 feet from the nearest rail and wait for the train to pass.

questions.questionText: Space cushion driving means:

answers.text: Keeping space around your vehicle on all sides
Driving in the center lane only

questions.explanation: A space cushion means maintaining adequate space on all sides of your vehicle to give you time to react to hazards.

questions.questionText: When driving near large trucks, you should avoid:
questions.explanation: Large trucks have significant blind spots on all sides. Avoid lingering in these 'no-zones' where the truck driver cannot see you.

questions.questionText: Driving distractions include:
questions.explanation: All of these are distractions that take your attention from driving. Avoid all distractions and focus on the road.

questions.questionText: When driving on a wet road, your following distance should be:

answers.text: The same as on dry roads

questions.explanation: On wet roads, you need at least twice the normal following distance because stopping distance increases significantly.

questions.questionText: If you see a pedestrian with a white cane or guide dog, you should:
questions.explanation: A white cane or guide dog indicates a blind pedestrian. You must stop and yield the right-of-way.

questions.questionText: North Carolina's Hands Free Law prohibits drivers from:

answers.text: Holding a mobile phone while driving
Having a phone in the car

questions.explanation: North Carolina's Hands Free Law (effective 2019) prohibits drivers from holding a mobile phone while driving. Hands-free use is permitted for those 18 and over.

questions.questionText: What is North Carolina's Move Over Law?

answers.text: Change lanes or slow down for stopped emergency vehicles

questions.explanation: The Move Over Law requires drivers to change lanes away from or slow down for stopped emergency, law enforcement, and utility vehicles with flashing lights.

questions.questionText: On North Carolina highways, the left lane is intended for:
questions.explanation: The left lane is for passing and faster-moving traffic. Slower traffic must keep right per the Slow Poke Law.

questions.questionText: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit on interstate highways in North Carolina is:
questions.explanation: The maximum speed limit on North Carolina interstate highways is 70 mph unless otherwise posted.

questions.questionText: You may turn right on red after stopping:

answers.text: Only if no sign prohibits it

questions.explanation: In North Carolina, you may turn right on red after coming to a complete stop and yielding to traffic, unless a sign prohibits it.

questions.questionText: During the first 6 months of a Limited Provisional License, a driver under 18 may not carry:

answers.text: More than one passenger under 21 who is not a family member

questions.explanation: For the first 6 months of a Limited Provisional License, drivers under 18 cannot have more than one passenger under 21 who is not a family member.

questions.questionText: Aggressive driving in North Carolina includes:

answers.text: Speeding, following too closely, unsafe lane changes

questions.explanation: Aggressive driving includes speeding, tailgating, unsafe lane changes, running red lights, and other dangerous behaviors.

questions.questionText: What is the speed limit in school zones when children are present?
questions.explanation: In North Carolina school zones, the speed limit is typically 25 mph when children are present or signs are flashing.

questions.questionText: If you approach a school bus with flashing red lights and a stop arm on a four-lane highway divided by a median, you must:

answers.text: Stop if traveling in either direction
Stop only if traveling in the same direction
Stop only if children are visible

questions.explanation: On a divided highway with a median, only traffic traveling in the same direction as the school bus must stop.

questions.questionText: Texting while driving is:
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is illegal for all drivers in North Carolina, regardless of age.

questions.questionText: Unless otherwise posted, what is the speed limit in residential areas?
questions.explanation: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit in residential areas in North Carolina is 35 mph.

questions.questionText: When must you use headlights in North Carolina?

answers.text: When wipers are in use and from sunset to sunrise

questions.explanation: North Carolina law requires headlights from sunset to sunrise and whenever windshield wipers are in continuous use.

questions.questionText: A Limited Learner Permit holder must be supervised by a licensed driver who is:

answers.text: At least 21 years old with at least one year of experience

questions.explanation: A Limited Learner Permit holder must be supervised by a licensed driver who is at least 21 years old with at least one year of driving experience.

questions.questionText: Seat belts must be worn by:
questions.explanation: North Carolina law requires all occupants of a vehicle to wear seat belts, regardless of seating position.

questions.questionText: At what age can you get a Limited Learner Permit in North Carolina?
questions.explanation: In North Carolina, you can apply for a Limited Learner Permit at age 15.

questions.questionText: The curfew for drivers under 18 with a Limited Provisional License is:
questions.explanation: Drivers under 18 with a Limited Provisional License cannot drive between 9 PM and 5 AM unless for work, school, or emergencies.

questions.questionText: When can you legally pass a vehicle on the right?

answers.text: On a one-way street or when the vehicle ahead is turning left

questions.explanation: You may pass on the right when on a one-way street, when the vehicle ahead is making a left turn, or on roads with two or more lanes in your direction.

questions.questionText: You must yield to pedestrians:

answers.text: Only when they have a walk signal
At all times when they are in the roadway

questions.explanation: Drivers must yield to pedestrians at all times when they are lawfully in the roadway, including crosswalks and intersections.

questions.questionText: When two vehicles arrive at an uncontrolled T-intersection at the same time:

answers.text: The vehicle on the through road has the right-of-way
The vehicle turning has the right-of-way
The larger vehicle has the right-of-way

questions.explanation: At a T-intersection, vehicles on the through road (the top of the T) have the right-of-way over vehicles on the terminating road.

questions.questionText: When making a left turn, you must yield to:

answers.text: Nothing if you have a green light

questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you must yield to all oncoming traffic and pedestrians crossing the street, even if you have a green light.

questions.questionText: Emergency vehicles with sirens and lights activated have:

answers.text: The right-of-way over all other traffic
The same rights as other vehicles

questions.explanation: Emergency vehicles with lights and sirens activated have the right-of-way. You must pull over and stop until they pass.

questions.questionText: Who has the right-of-way at a roundabout?
questions.explanation: Vehicles already circulating in the roundabout have the right-of-way. Entering vehicles must yield.

questions.questionText: When you hear a siren or see flashing lights from an emergency vehicle, you should:

answers.text: Speed up to get out of the way
Pull to the right and stop

questions.explanation: When an emergency vehicle approaches with lights and sirens, pull to the right side of the road and stop until it passes.

questions.questionText: You must stop for a school bus:

answers.text: When its red lights are flashing and stop arm is extended

questions.explanation: You must stop when a school bus displays flashing red lights and extends its stop arm, indicating children are loading or unloading.

questions.questionText: At a four-way stop, if two cars arrive at different times:

answers.text: The vehicle that arrived first goes first
The vehicle on the right goes first
Both go at the same time

questions.explanation: At a four-way stop, vehicles proceed in the order they arrived. The first vehicle to stop is the first to go.

questions.questionText: When entering traffic from a parked position, you should:

answers.text: Expect traffic to stop for you

questions.explanation: When entering traffic from a parked position, signal your intention and yield to traffic already on the roadway.

questions.questionText: You are driving and an emergency vehicle approaches from behind. You should:

answers.text: Pull to the right and stop

questions.explanation: Pull to the right side of the road and come to a complete stop until the emergency vehicle passes.

questions.questionText: At an intersection with a flashing yellow light, you must:

answers.text: Slow down and proceed with caution
Treat it as a four-way stop

questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light means slow down and proceed with caution. Be prepared to yield if necessary.

questions.questionText: When approaching a yield sign, you must:

answers.text: Always come to a complete stop
Slow down and yield to traffic

questions.explanation: At a yield sign, slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary to yield the right-of-way to other vehicles or pedestrians.

questions.questionText: Funeral processions have the right-of-way:

answers.text: When led by an escort vehicle

questions.explanation: Funeral processions led by an escort vehicle have the right-of-way. Do not interrupt or pass through a procession.

questions.questionText: When turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should turn into:

answers.text: The lane closest to the center line

questions.explanation: When turning left onto a one-way street, turn into the lane closest to the center line of the road you are entering.

questions.questionText: Mail carriers and newspaper delivery drivers have:

answers.text: Limited parking privileges while making deliveries

questions.explanation: Mail carriers and delivery drivers have limited privileges to stop briefly for deliveries, but other traffic laws still apply.

questions.questionText: A green arrow pointing left at an intersection means:

answers.text: You may turn left but must yield to pedestrians
You may turn left and have the right-of-way

questions.explanation: A green arrow means you may proceed in the direction of the arrow and have the right-of-way over other traffic.

questions.questionText: When exiting a driveway or alley, you must:

answers.text: Yield to all traffic and pedestrians

questions.explanation: When exiting a private driveway or alley, you must stop and yield to all traffic and pedestrians on the sidewalk or roadway.

questions.questionText: If you arrive at a stop sign at the same time as another vehicle on your right:

answers.text: The vehicle on the right has the right-of-way
Both proceed at the same time

questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive at a stop sign simultaneously, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way.

questions.questionText: In North Carolina, the separate road signs test requires you to correctly identify:
questions.explanation: North Carolina requires a separate road signs test where applicants must correctly identify 10 out of 12 signs (80%) by shape and color.

questions.questionText: The 'Fender Bender' law in North Carolina requires drivers to:

answers.text: Move vehicles to the shoulder if no injuries and vehicles are operable
Leave the scene if damage is minor
Wait in the travel lane for police

questions.explanation: NC's Fender Bender law requires drivers to move vehicles out of the travel lane to the shoulder if there are no injuries and vehicles are operable.

questions.questionText: North Carolina's Slow Poke Law specifically requires:

answers.text: All traffic to use the right lane
Slower traffic to keep right on multi-lane highways
Trucks to stay right at all times

questions.explanation: The Slow Poke Law requires slower-moving traffic to keep right on multi-lane highways, keeping the left lane available for passing.

questions.questionText: In North Carolina, drivers under 18 are prohibited from using cell phones:
questions.explanation: North Carolina law prohibits all cell phone use (including hands-free) for drivers under 18, except in emergency situations.

questions.questionText: A Limited Learner Permit in North Carolina allows driving:

answers.text: Only with a supervising driver age 21+ with 1 year experience

questions.explanation: A Limited Learner Permit requires supervision by a licensed driver age 21 or older with at least one year of driving experience.

questions.questionText: North Carolina's Graduated Licensing system includes how many levels?
questions.explanation: North Carolina has three levels: Level 1 (Limited Learner Permit), Level 2 (Limited Provisional License), and Level 3 (Full Provisional License).

questions.questionText: The North Carolina Move Over Law applies to:

answers.text: Emergency, law enforcement, utility, and DOT vehicles

questions.explanation: The Move Over Law applies to emergency vehicles, law enforcement, utility vehicles, tow trucks, and DOT vehicles with activated lights.

questions.questionText: Under North Carolina law, a Level 1 Limited Learner Permit holder must hold the permit for at least:
questions.explanation: A Level 1 Limited Learner Permit must be held for at least 12 months before advancing to a Level 2 Limited Provisional License.

questions.questionText: For the first 6 months with a Limited Provisional License, drivers under 18 cannot drive between:
questions.explanation: For the first 6 months of a Limited Provisional License, drivers under 18 cannot drive between 9 PM and 5 AM without a valid exception.

questions.questionText: North Carolina's implied consent law means:

answers.text: You can refuse a chemical test
By driving, you consent to chemical testing if suspected of DWI

questions.explanation: Implied consent means that by driving in NC, you automatically consent to chemical testing if suspected of DWI. Refusal results in license revocation.

questions.questionText: In North Carolina, how many points on your license within 3 years can result in suspension?
questions.explanation: Accumulating 12 or more points within 3 years can result in license suspension in North Carolina.

questions.questionText: When the North Carolina Move Over Law cannot be safely followed, you must:

answers.text: Slow down to a safe speed below the posted limit

questions.explanation: If you cannot safely move over for emergency vehicles, you must slow down to a safe speed below the posted limit and proceed with caution.

questions.questionText: North Carolina's Hands Free Law was enacted in:
questions.explanation: North Carolina's Hands Free Law prohibiting hand-held mobile phone use while driving was enacted in 2019.

questions.questionText: After 6 months with a Limited Provisional License, passenger restrictions:
questions.explanation: After the first 6 months of a Limited Provisional License, the passenger restriction (no more than one under-21 non-family member) is lifted.

questions.questionText: In North Carolina, the legal blood alcohol concentration (BAC) limit for drivers 21 and over is:
questions.explanation: The legal BAC limit for drivers 21 and over in North Carolina is 0.08%. Any higher constitutes Driving While Impaired (DWI).

questions.questionText: For drivers under 21, the legal BAC limit in North Carolina is:
questions.explanation: North Carolina has a zero-tolerance policy for drivers under 21. Any detectable amount of alcohol can result in charges.

questions.questionText: DWI stands for:
questions.explanation: In North Carolina, DWI stands for Driving While Impaired, which includes impairment by alcohol, drugs, or any impairing substance.

questions.questionText: If convicted of DWI, you may face:

answers.text: License suspension, fines, and possible jail time

questions.explanation: DWI conviction can result in license suspension, substantial fines, increased insurance rates, mandatory substance abuse assessment, and possible jail time.

questions.questionText: The only way to sober up is to:
questions.explanation: Time is the only way to reduce blood alcohol concentration. Coffee, showers, and exercise do not speed up the process.

questions.questionText: Driving under the influence of prescription drugs:

answers.text: Is legal if prescribed to you
Can result in a DWI if they impair your driving
Is only illegal for certain medications

questions.explanation: Even legal prescription drugs can result in DWI charges if they impair your ability to drive safely.

questions.questionText: Alcohol affects:
questions.explanation: Alcohol impairs judgment, reaction time, vision, coordination, and decision-making abilities, all critical for safe driving.

questions.questionText: If you refuse a chemical test when suspected of DWI:

answers.text: Your license will be immediately revoked for at least one year
You can take the test later

questions.explanation: Under NC's implied consent law, refusing a chemical test results in immediate license revocation for at least one year.

questions.questionText: Combining alcohol with other drugs:
questions.explanation: Combining alcohol with other drugs, including over-the-counter medications, can multiply the impairing effects and is extremely dangerous.

questions.questionText: The average person metabolizes alcohol at a rate of approximately:
questions.explanation: The liver metabolizes alcohol at approximately one standard drink per hour, though this varies by individual.

questions.questionText: If you are convicted of DWI and someone was seriously injured, you may be charged with:
questions.explanation: DWI resulting in serious injury or death can be charged as a felony in North Carolina, carrying severe penalties including prison time.

questions.questionText: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit on North Carolina primary and secondary roads outside city limits is:
questions.explanation: On primary and secondary roads outside city limits, the default speed limit is 55 mph unless otherwise posted.

questions.questionText: In North Carolina, you must reduce your speed:

answers.text: When conditions require it for safety

questions.explanation: You must always drive at a speed that is reasonable and prudent for conditions, which may be below the posted limit.

questions.questionText: Speeding in a school zone can result in:

answers.text: The same penalty as other speeding

questions.explanation: Speeding in a school zone during posted hours typically results in doubled fines due to the increased danger to children.

questions.questionText: On a four-lane highway with a median, unless posted otherwise, the speed limit is:
questions.explanation: On divided highways (four lanes with a median), the default speed limit is typically 65 mph unless otherwise posted.

questions.questionText: When approaching a work zone with workers present, you should:

answers.text: Speed up to clear the area quickly

questions.explanation: Work zones often have reduced speed limits when workers are present. Obey all posted work zone speed limits for everyone's safety.

questions.questionText: Driving too slowly can be:
questions.explanation: Driving significantly below the speed limit can be illegal and create hazards by impeding traffic flow and causing dangerous speed differentials.

questions.questionText: Speed limits are based on ideal conditions. In bad weather, you should:

answers.text: Drive at the posted speed limit
Drive faster to reduce time on the road
Reduce your speed below the posted limit

questions.explanation: Speed limits assume ideal conditions. In rain, fog, ice, or snow, you must reduce speed below the posted limit for safety.

questions.questionText: Speeding violations in North Carolina result in:

answers.text: Points on your license and fines

questions.explanation: Speeding violations result in points on your license, fines, increased insurance rates, and possible license suspension.

questions.questionText: You must not park within ___ feet of a stop sign.
questions.explanation: You must not park within 30 feet of a stop sign in North Carolina to ensure visibility for other drivers.

questions.questionText: When parking on a hill without a curb, you should turn your wheels:

answers.text: Toward the side of the road
Away from the side of the road

questions.explanation: When parking on a hill without a curb, turn wheels toward the side of the road so the vehicle will roll off the road if brakes fail.

questions.questionText: When parking uphill with a curb, you should turn your wheels:
questions.explanation: When parking uphill with a curb, turn wheels away from the curb so if the vehicle rolls back, the rear of the front tire will hit the curb.

questions.questionText: Parking in a space reserved for disabled persons without proper authorization:

answers.text: Is allowed if you're only stopping briefly
Results in fines and possible towing
Is acceptable if no other spaces are available

questions.explanation: Parking in a disabled space without proper authorization results in substantial fines and possible vehicle towing.

questions.questionText: When parking downhill with a curb, you should turn your wheels:
questions.explanation: When parking downhill with a curb, turn wheels toward the curb so the vehicle will roll into the curb if brakes fail.

questions.questionText: You must not park within ___ feet of a crosswalk.
questions.explanation: You must not park within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection to ensure pedestrian visibility.

questions.questionText: Double parking (parking next to another parked vehicle) is:
questions.explanation: Double parking is illegal as it blocks traffic flow and creates a hazard for other drivers.

questions.questionText: If your gas pedal sticks, you should:
questions.explanation: If your gas pedal sticks, shift to neutral immediately, apply brakes, and pull off the road safely. Then turn off the engine.

questions.questionText: If your headlights fail at night, you should:

answers.text: Use emergency flashers and pull off the road
Speed up to reach your destination quickly

questions.explanation: If headlights fail at night, turn on emergency flashers and carefully pull off the road to a safe location.

questions.questionText: If you are in a crash, you should:

answers.text: Stop, check for injuries, call 911 if needed, and exchange information

questions.explanation: After a crash, stop immediately, check for injuries, call 911 if needed, move vehicles if possible, and exchange information with other drivers.

questions.questionText: If your engine overheats, you should:

answers.text: Pull over, turn off the engine, and wait for it to cool
Pour cold water on the engine

questions.explanation: If your engine overheats, pull over safely, turn off the engine, and wait for it to cool before checking coolant. Never open a hot radiator cap.

questions.questionText: If you see smoke coming from under your hood, you should:

answers.text: Pull over, turn off engine, get away from vehicle, and call 911

questions.explanation: If you see smoke or fire, pull over immediately, turn off the engine, evacuate everyone from the vehicle, move to a safe distance, and call 911.

questions.questionText: If you witness a crash, you should:

answers.text: Stop safely, call 911, and provide assistance if trained

questions.explanation: If you witness a crash, pull over safely, call 911, protect the scene, and provide first aid only if you are trained to do so.

questions.questionText: Driving 15 mph over the speed limit in North Carolina typically results in:
questions.explanation: Speeding more than 10 mph over the limit typically results in 3 points on your license in North Carolina.

questions.questionText: Running a red light in North Carolina results in:
questions.explanation: Running a red light or stop sign results in 3 points on your driver's license in North Carolina.

questions.questionText: Reckless driving in North Carolina carries:
questions.explanation: Reckless driving is a serious offense that carries 4 points on your license in North Carolina.

questions.questionText: Points stay on your driving record in North Carolina for:
questions.explanation: Points remain on your driving record for 3 years from the date of conviction in North Carolina.

questions.questionText: Failing to yield right-of-way results in:
questions.explanation: Failing to yield right-of-way carries 3 points on your license in North Carolina.

questions.questionText: Accumulating how many points in one year triggers a warning letter from the DMV?
questions.explanation: Accumulating 7 points within one year triggers a warning letter from the NC DMV about potential license suspension.

questions.questionText: Leaving the scene of a crash can result in:

answers.text: Criminal charges, license revocation, and jail time

questions.explanation: Leaving the scene of a crash (hit and run) is a serious crime that can result in criminal charges, license revocation, and imprisonment.
